verses.text: So these three men stopped answering Job, because he considered himself righteous.
verses.comment: Job's insistence on his own righteousness silences his friends. The concept of personal righteousness is later fulfilled in Christ, who alone is truly righteous (Rom. 3:10).

verses.text: Then Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, became angry. He was angry at Job for justifying himself rather than God.
verses.comment: Elihu's zeal reflects the importance of upholding God's justice. This hints at the need for an interpreter between God and humanity, later fulfilled in Jesus (1 Tim. 2:5).

verses.text: He was also angry with Job's three friends, because they had not found an answer, and yet had condemned Job.
verses.comment: Condemnation without sufficient reason or truth is cautioned against here, pointing to the call for true judgment and mercy seen in Jesus' teachings (Matt. 7:1-5).

verses.text: Now Elihu had waited to speak to Job because the others were older than he.
verses.comment: Respect for elders is recognized here; wisdom is often attributed to age, yet true understanding comes from the Spirit (Job 32:8).

verses.text: But when Elihu saw that the three men had nothing more to say, his anger burned.
verses.comment: Elihu’s righteous anger resembles prophetic zeal, a theme seen in God’s chosen spokespersons who defend divine justice (see Jer. 20:9).

verses.text: So Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite said, 'I am young in years, and you are old; that is why I was afraid to tell you what I think.'
verses.comment: Elihu’s humility in addressing the elders reflects the virtue of humility, which is exalted throughout Scripture (Prov. 11:2; Luke 14:11).

verses.text: 'I thought, “Age should speak; advanced years should teach wisdom.”'
verses.comment: Tradition holds that age imparts wisdom, but Elihu will argue for the source of true understanding: the Spirit. This anticipates the New Covenant outpouring (Acts 2:17).

verses.text: 'But it is the spirit in a person, the breath of the Almighty, that gives them understanding.'
verses.comment: True wisdom comes from God's Spirit. Elihu’s words foreshadow Pentecost and apostolic teaching guided by the Spirit (John 14:26).

verses.text: 'It is not only the old who are wise, nor only the aged who understand what is right.'
verses.comment: God grants understanding beyond age, consistent with how God calls the young (Jer. 1:7) and the lowly for His purposes (1 Cor. 1:27).

verses.text: 'Therefore I say: Listen to me; I too will tell you what I know.'
verses.comment: Elihu invites the elders to hear his perspective, emphasizing the necessity of all members contributing to discernment in spiritual matters (Acts 15:7-12).

verses.text: 'I waited while you spoke, listened to your reasoning; while you searched for words,'
verses.comment: Elihu's patience models the virtue of endurance and careful listening, key components for discernment (James 1:19).

verses.text: 'I paid close attention to you; not one of you has proved Job wrong, nor answered his arguments.'
verses.comment: Elihu notes the failure of Job’s friends, paralleling occasions when Jesus silenced His questioners by wisdom (Matt. 22:46).

verses.text: 'Do not say, “We have found wisdom; let God deal with him, not a man.”'
verses.comment: Elihu warns against presuming possession of wisdom; ultimate judgment and vindication belongs to God, who is both just and merciful.

verses.text: 'Job has not directed his words against me, and I will not use your arguments.'
verses.comment: Elihu prepares to offer a new perspective, reminiscent of later prophetic voices who reveal deeper truths from the Spirit (John 16:13).

verses.text: 'They are dismayed and have no more answers; words have failed them.'
verses.comment: Human wisdom reaches its limits, emphasizing the necessity of divine revelation—a recurring theme throughout salvation history.

verses.text: 'Should I wait, now that they are silent, now that they stand there with no reply?'
verses.comment: Elihu's rhetorical question prepares the reader for a fresh word of truth—God often raises up new voices to speak when others fall silent.

verses.text: 'I too will answer; I too will tell what I know.'
verses.comment: Elihu presents himself as a valid voice among the assembly, reflecting the collaborative discernment seen in apostolic tradition (Acts 15:13).

verses.text: 'For I am full of words, and the spirit within me compels me.'
verses.comment: Elihu is moved by the Spirit, showing that true speech on behalf of God is divinely inspired (2 Peter 1:21).

verses.text: 'Inside, I am like wine that has no vent, like new wineskins ready to burst.'
verses.comment: The imagery recalls Jesus’ teaching on new wine and new wineskins, symbolizing new revelation and the need for hearts open to spiritual truth.

verses.text: 'I must speak so that I may find relief; I must open my lips and answer.'
verses.comment: Speaking truth brings spiritual relief; God’s prophets and witnesses often find they must declare the word (Acts 4:20).

verses.text: 'I will show no partiality, nor will I flatter anyone.'
verses.comment: Elihu’s refusal to show partiality echoes God’s own impartial justice, a theme developed throughout Scripture (Deut. 10:17; James 2:1).

verses.text: 'For if I were skilled in flattery, my Maker would soon take me away.'
verses.comment: False speech and hypocrisy lead to judgment. Authentic witness is valued, and Elihu’s warning anticipates Jesus’ condemnation of hypocrisy (Matt. 23:27-28).
